  • • Option C. Stool antigen test
  • • Option D. Endoscopic biopsy for histology : While accurate, endoscopy is invasive and not recommended as an initial test for patients without alarm symptoms.
  • • Option D. Endoscopic biopsy for histology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For initial testing of Helicobacter pylori in patients with dyspepsia and no alarming features, the non-invasive and accurate urea breath test is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: Which test is most appropriate to diagnose H. pylori infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stool antigen test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Serologic antibody test : It is not the best choice for diagnosis because it cannot differentiate between past and current infection.
  • • Option A. Serologic antibody test
  • • Option B. Urea breath test : This test is reliable but should be avoided if the patient is on proton pump inhibitors or bismuth, which can lead to false negatives.
  • • Option B. Urea breath test
  • • Option D. Endoscopic biopsy for histology : While accurate, it is invasive and typically reserved for patients with alarm symptoms or those in whom endoscopy is otherwise indicated.
  • • Option D. Endoscopic biopsy for histology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The stool antigen test is the preferred non-invasive method for diagnosing active H. pylori infection, especially in patients taking iron supplements, which do not interfere with test results.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a six-month history of nocturnal epigastric pain relieved by eating and antacids, with no alarming symptoms. To assess for past exposure to H. pylori, which test should be performed?

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic biopsy with rapid urease test

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serologic antibody test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Urea breath test : This test is used to diagnose current active infection or to confirm eradication after treatment, but it is not used to determine past exposure.
  • • Option A. Urea breath test
  • • Option B. Fecal antigen test : Like the urea breath test, it is used to diagnose active infections and confirm eradication post-treatment.
  • • Option B. Fecal antigen test
  • • Option D. Endoscopic biopsy with rapid urease test : This is an invasive test for current infection, typically used if endoscopy is indicated for other reasons, such as alarm symptoms or failure of initial treatment.
  • • Option D. Endoscopic biopsy with rapid urease test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The serologic antibody test can determine past exposure to H. pylori but cannot differentiate between current and past infection. It is not the test of choice for diagnosing active infection or for confirming eradication after treatment.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for H. pylori infection in a patient with no prior antibiotic exposure and no contraindications is triple therapy?

options.label: B
options.text: Metronidazole, tetracycline, bismuth subsalicylate, and omeprazole

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clarithromycin, amoxicillin, and omeprazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Metronidazole, tetracycline, bismuth subsalicylate, and omeprazole : This quadruple therapy is an alternative, particularly in areas of high clarithromycin resistance or for patients with previous macrolide exposure.
  • • Option B. Metronidazole, tetracycline, bismuth subsalicylate, and omeprazole
  • • Option C. Amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, and ranitidine : This combination is not a standard regimen for H. pylori eradication and includes a fluoroquinolone and an H2 blocker, which is less effective than a proton pump inhibitor in this setting.
  • • Option C. Amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, and ranitidine
  • • Option D. Metronidazole, ciprofloxacin, and lansoprazole : This regimen does not follow the recommended guidelines for H. pylori treatment due to the inclusion of ciprofloxacin, which is not a first-line agent for this infection.
  • • Option D. Metronidazole, ciprofloxacin, and lansoprazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The initial treatment for H. pylori infection should consist of triple therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (like omeprazole) and two antibiotics (clarithromycin and amoxicillin) for 14 days to effectively eradicate the infection and promote ulcer healing.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male hiker presents with several months of progressive weakness, joint pains, unexplained weight loss, intermittent diarrhea, recent episodes of uveitis and abdominal discomfort. Examination reveals hyperpigmentation of the skin, particularly around the eyes. Laboratory tests show anemia and a low serum albumin level. Endoscopic biopsy of the small intestine reveals numerous macrophages laden with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive granules in the lamina propria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Whipple's Disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Sarcoidosis : This systemic granulomatous disease can cause similar systemic symptoms and hyperpigmentation, but it does not exhibit PAS-positive macrophages on intestinal biopsy.
  • • Option A. Sarcoidosis
  • • Option C. Lymphoma : While GI lymphoma may present with weight loss and abdominal pain, it does not show PAS-positive macrophages on biopsy.
  • • Option C. Lymphoma
  • • Option D. Amyloidosis : This condition can lead to systemic symptoms and gastrointestinal involvement, but the biopsy would show amyloid deposits, not PAS-positive macrophages.
  • • Option D. Amyloidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Whipple's disease should be suspected in patients with systemic symptoms, including arthralgias, gastrointestinal complaints, and hyperpigmentation, especially when intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this Whipple’s disease ?

options.label: A
options.text: Long-term antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

questions.correct_answer: A. Long-term antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Long-term antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Gluten-free diet : This is the treatment for celiac disease, not Whipple's disease.
  • • Option B. Gluten-free diet
  • • Option C. High-dose corticosteroids : Steroids are not the primary treatment for Whipple's disease and are typically used for conditions with significant inflammation, like autoimmune diseases.
  • • Option C. High-dose corticosteroids
  • • Option D. Chemotherapy : Used for treating malignancies, not infectious diseases like Whipple's disease.
  • • Option D. Chemotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The appropriate treatment for Whipple's disease involves initial antibiotic therapy, typically with ceftriaxone or penicillin G, followed by prolonged oral therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole to eradicate the infection and prevent relapse.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and vitamin B12 deficiency. She has a history of type 2 diabetes and underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery 5 years ago. Her symptoms are partially relieved by antibiotics. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Lactose intolerance : Typically presents with symptoms after dairy consumption, but does not cause vitamin B12 deficiency or improve with antibiotics.
  • • Option A. Lactose intolerance
  • • Option B. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) : While IBS can cause similar symptoms, it does not lead to vitamin B12 deficiency and is not typically relieved by antibiotics.
  • • Option B. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
  • • Option D. Celiac disease : Could explain the symptoms and vitamin deficiency, but the relief with antibiotics is more characteristic of SIBO.
  • • Option D. Celiac disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In patients with chronic gastrointestinal symptoms, vitamin deficiencies, and a history that predisposes to bacterial overgrowth, SIBO should be considered, especially when symptoms improve with antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue following a 6-month volunteer trip to Southeast Asia. She reports a significant decrease in appetite and has noted her stools to be bulky and foul-smelling. Laboratory tests reveal iron-deficiency anemia and folate deficiency. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tropical Sprue

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Celiac Disease : While celiac disease can cause similar gastrointestinal symptoms and malabsorption, it is not typically associated with travel to tropical regions.
  • • Option A. Celiac Disease
  • • Option B. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) : IBS primarily presents with abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits but does not typically cause significant malabsorption or nutrient deficiencies.
  • • Option B. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
  • • Option D. Giardiasis : This parasitic infection can cause diarrhea and malabsorption but is usually acute in nature and would likely resolve on its own or with appropriate treatment within a few weeks to months.
  • • Option D. Giardiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Tropical Sprue should be considered in patients with chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and nutrient deficiencies, particularly if they have a history of extended travel or residency in tropical regions and symptoms persist despite returning to a non-tropical environment.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to concerns about poor coordination, developmental delay and chronic diarrhea since infancy. Physical examination reveals a thin child with steatorrhea and acanthocytosis on blood smear. Laboratory tests indicate very low levels of cholesterol and triglycerides, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Abetalipoproteinemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Cystic Fibrosis : This genetic disorder can cause malabsorption and growth delay but is more commonly associated with respiratory symptoms and does not typically present with acanthocytosis or the specific lipid profile seen in abetalipoproteinemia.
  • • Option A. Cystic Fibrosis
  • • Option B. Celiac Disease : While celiac disease can lead to malabsorption and growth problems, it does not cause the lipid abnormalities or acanthocytosis associated with abetalipoproteinemia.
  • • Option B. Celiac Disease
  • • Option D. Pancreatic Insufficiency : This condition can lead to steatorrhea and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies but does not cause the abnormal lipid profile or acanthocytosis seen in abetalipoproteinemia.
  • • Option D. Pancreatic Insufficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In patients presenting with chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, neurological symptoms, acanthocytosis, and very low levels of cholesterol and triglycerides, consider abetalipoproteinemia, especially if fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies are present.

questions.text: During an endoscopic examination of a 59-year-old male with a history of hematemesis, an ulcer in the duodenum is found to have a flat, pigmented spot at the base. There is no active bleeding or visible vessel. How should this ulcer be classified according to the Forrest classification?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Forrest III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Forrest Ia: Ulcers have active spurting hemorrhage, which is not present in this patient.
  • • Option A. Forrest Ia:
  • • Option B. Forrest Ib: Ulcers have active oozing bleeding, not evident in this scenario.
  • • Option B. Forrest Ib:
  • • Option C. Forrest IIb: Ulcers have a non-bleeding visible vessel or an adherent clot, which is different from the described flat pigmented spot.
  • • Option C. Forrest IIb:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A duodenal ulcer with a flat pigmented spot and no active bleeding is Forrest III, which is associated with a low risk of rebleeding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a history of recurrent abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea has undergone multiple colonoscopies over the past 3 years, all showing continuous inflammation of the mucosa extending from the rectum to the transverse colon. There is no evidence of granulomas on biopsy. Which feature is most suggestive of her underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Continuous mucosal involvement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Skip lesions : Characteristic of Crohn's Disease, which involves patchy areas of inflammation separated by healthy tissue along the digestive tract.
  • • Option A. Skip lesions
  • • Option B. Granuloma formation : Also more typical of Crohn's Disease, where non-caseating granulomas can often be found on biopsy.
  • • Option B. Granuloma formation
  • • Option D. Transmural inflammation : Suggestive of Crohn's Disease, as it involves the entire thickness of the bowel wall, unlike the superficial involvement seen in Ulcerative Colitis.
  • • Option D. Transmural inflammation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Continuous mucosal involvement without granulomas, especially from the rectum to more proximal parts of the colon, suggests Ulcerative Colitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) predominantly with constipation (IBS-C) can be prescribed which drug to alleviate constipation and abdominal discomfort. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lubiprostone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Loperamide : Primarily used to manage diarrhea (IBS-D) due to its antidiarrheal effects, not suitable for IBS-C.
  • • Option B. Loperamide
  • • Option C. Broad-spectrum antibiotics : May be used in specific cases like Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO), but not typically for IBS-C without evidence of SIBO.
  • • Option C. Broad-spectrum antibiotics
  • • Option D. Gluten-free diet : While some patients with IBS may report sensitivity to gluten, a gluten-free diet is not a standard treatment for IBS-C and is more specific to conditions like celiac disease.
  • • Option D. Gluten-free diet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For IBS-C, when dietary fiber is insufficient, medications like lubiprostone that enhance intestinal fluid secretion can be effective in managing symptoms.

questions.text: Which medication would be most appropriate to add in the management plan of severe IBS-D in men and women when other treatments have not been effective?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alosetron

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Psyllium : A soluble fiber that can help manage both IBS-C and IBS-D, but might not be sufficient for severe IBS-D cases.
  • • Option B. Psyllium
  • • Option C. Omeprazole : A proton pump inhibitor used for acid-related disorders, not typically used for IBS-D.
  • • Option C. Omeprazole
  • • Option D. Metformin : Used in the management of type 2 diabetes, not IBS-D.
  • • Option D. Metformin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For patients with severe IBS-D not adequately managed by dietary modifications, alosetron can be considered under a risk management program due to its efficacy in reducing diarrhea and bowel urgency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a recent onset of fever. She has a history of mouth ulcers. Imaging studies reveal thickening of the terminal ileum and the presence of a fistula. Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Crohn's Disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Ulcerative Colitis : Typically involves continuous inflammation of the colon starting from the rectum, without fistulas or mouth ulcers.
  • • Option B. Ulcerative Colitis
  • • Option C. Diverticulitis : Involves the inflammation or infection of diverticula in the colon, not commonly associated with terminal ileum involvement or fistula formation in this context.
  • • Option C. Diverticulitis
  • • Option D. Gastroenteritis : Generally presents with acute onset of diarrhea and vomiting due to infection, not typically associated with chronic inflammation, thickening of the ileum, or fistulas.
  • • Option D. Gastroenteritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Terminal ileum involvement, fistula formation, and mouth ulcers strongly indicate Crohn's Disease among inflammatory bowel diseases.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with a diagnosis of Crohn's Disease presents with moderate to severe flare-up symptoms despite oral corticosteroid therapy. His medical history includes a partial ileal resection. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the dose of oral corticosteroids

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Start infliximab therapy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Increase the dose of oral corticosteroids : Not advisable due to the risk of steroid dependency and side effects, particularly in cases unresponsive to initial corticosteroid therapy.
  • • Option A. Increase the dose of oral corticosteroids
  • • Option B. Initiate 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) therapy : 5-ASA is more commonly used in mild to moderate ulcerative colitis and has limited efficacy in Crohn's Disease, especially in moderate to severe cases.
  • • Option B. Initiate 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) therapy
  • • Option D. Surgical resection of affected segments : Surgery may be considered for complications or disease refractory to medical therapy, but it is not the first step following corticosteroid failure.
  • • Option D. Surgical resection of affected segments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In moderate to severe Crohn's Disease unresponsive to corticosteroids, anti-TNF agents like infliximab are effective in inducing and maintaining remission.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with Crohn's Disease has mild ileocolic involvement controlled with budesonide. She is planning to conceive. What is the most appropriate management to maintain remission during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Continue budesonide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Discontinue all medications : Discontinuing effective treatment could lead to a flare-up, which poses a greater risk to both the mother and the fetus than the medication itself.
  • • Option A. Discontinue all medications
  • • Option B. Switch to oral mesalamine : While mesalamine is generally safe in pregnancy, there's no need to switch if budesonide is effectively controlling the disease.
  • • Option B. Switch to oral mesalamine
  • • Option D. Initiate azathioprine : Azathioprine can be used during pregnancy for IBD management, but it's typically reserved for more severe disease or when other treatments are ineffective.
  • • Option D. Initiate azathioprine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Budesonide can be safely continued during pregnancy to maintain remission in patients with mild Crohn's Disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of polycythemia vera presents with gradual onset of diffuse abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea over the past week. She denies any cardiac history. Laboratory tests show elevated white blood cells and lactate. CT abdomen reveals venous dilatation and edema in the bowel wall without arterial occlusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute mesenteric ischemia due to arterial embolism

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mesenteric venous thrombosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Acute mesenteric ischemia due to arterial embolism : Typically presents suddenly with severe pain, often in patients with a cardiac source of emboli.
  • • Option A. Acute mesenteric ischemia due to arterial embolism
  • • Option B. Chronic mesenteric ischemia : Presents with postprandial pain and weight loss over months to years, not with acute symptoms.
  • • Option B. Chronic mesenteric ischemia
  • • Option D. Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia : Occurs in low-flow states such as heart failure or sepsis, and is characterized by diffuse pain without a clear occlusive source on imaging.
  • • Option D. Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mesenteric venous thrombosis should be considered in patients with a hypercoagulable state presenting with gradual onset of abdominal pain and specific CT findings, even without arterial occlusion.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man with a history of heart failure and recent myocardial infarction is admitted to the ICU for management of cardiogenic shock. He subsequently develops diffuse abdominal pain,bloody diarrhea and hypotension. Abdominal imaging shows diffuse small bowel wall thickening with patent mesenteric vessels. What is the most likely cause of his abdominal symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute mesenteric ischemia due to arterial embolism

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Explanation :
  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Acute mesenteric ischemia due to arterial embolism : Typically presents suddenly in patients with a source for emboli (e.g., atrial fibrillation), not primarily associated with low-flow states.
  • • Option A. Acute mesenteric ischemia due to arterial embolism
  • • Option B. Chronic mesenteric ischemia : Manifests with postprandial abdominal pain and weight loss over months to years, not acutely in the setting of cardiogenic shock.
  • • Option B. Chronic mesenteric ischemia
  • • Option C. Mesenteric venous thrombosis : Presents with gradual onset abdominal pain, often associated with hypercoagulable states, and would show venous occlusion on imaging.
  • • Option C. Mesenteric venous thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In patients with systemic low-flow states, such as cardiogenic shock, presenting with acute abdominal symptoms and diffuse bowel wall changes without vessel occlusion, consider nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: In a 52-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse presenting with hematemesis, jaundice, ascites, palmar erythema, spider angiomata, thrombocytopenia, and prolonged PT/INR, what is the most appropriate diagnostic procedure to identify the bleeding source?

options.label: C
options.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Abdominal ultrasound: Abdominal ultrasound is useful for evaluating the liver, spleen, and portal vein, which could help in assessing the chronic liver disease but is not the immediate test for active upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • • Option A. Abdominal ultrasound:
  • • Option C. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is helpful in the evaluation of abdominal structures and can provide information about the liver and spleen, but it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for an active variceal bleed.
  • • Option C. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen:
  • • Option D. Barium swallow study: A barium swallow study may be used to evaluate structural abnormalities of the esophagus and stomach, but it is contraindicated in the setting of an active bleed as it can interfere with endoscopic therapeutic procedures.
  • • Option D. Barium swallow study:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EGD is the immediate and most appropriate next step in the diagnosis and potential treatment of variceal bleeding in a patient with signs of portal hypertension and cirrhosis.

questions.text: For a 50-year-old male with cirrhosis due to hepatitis C presenting with acute hematemesis, jaundice, ascites, and palmar erythema, who has been stabilized with IV fluids, the best immediate pharmacotherapy is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous octreotide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Oral propranolol: Is used in the primary prevention of variceal bleeding, not in the acute setting.
  • • Option A. Oral propranolol:
  • • Option C. Intravenous ceftriaxone: Is indicated for infection prophylaxis in cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal bleeding, but it is not the primary treatment for the bleed itself.
  • • Option C. Intravenous ceftriaxone:
  • • Option D. Oral omeprazole: Is a proton pump inhibitor that may help with peptic ulcers but is not the first-line treatment for acute variceal bleeding.
  • • Option D. Oral omeprazole:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous octreotide is the initial pharmacological treatment in the acute management of variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with cirrhosis is admitted to the hospital with a variceal bleed. He has been resuscitated and received octreotide and endoscopic band ligation. The next day, he develops melena. His hemoglobin has dropped from 8.5 g/dL on admission to 7.8 g/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion

options.label: B
options.text: Arrange for an urgent repeat endoscop

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a tagged red blood cell scan

options.label: D
options.text: Prepare for emergent transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure

questions.correct_answer: B. Arrange for an urgent repeat endoscop
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arrange for an urgent repeat endoscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Start a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion is adjunctive therapy for peptic ulcer disease but would not be the most appropriate next step for suspected ongoing variceal bleeding.
  • • Option A. Start a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion:
  • • Option C. Perform a tagged red blood cell scan : A tagged red blood cell scan is a diagnostic procedure to localize sites of slow gastrointestinal bleeding but is not appropriate for acute rebleeding where endoscopy is indicated.
  • • Option C. Perform a tagged red blood cell scan
  • • Option D. Prepare for emergent transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure: A transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is considered if endoscopic treatment fails or is not possible; it is not the immediate next step after a drop in hemoglobin without first reassessing endoscopically.
  • • Option D. Prepare for emergent transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An urgent repeat endoscopy is indicated in a patient with cirrhosis who develops signs of ongoing variceal bleeding post-initial endoscopic treatment.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Colonoscopy shows continuous mucosal inflammation and ulceration limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon. Biopsy findings include crypt abscesses and mucosal inflammation. Which condition do these findings most likely suggest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulcerative Colitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Crohn's Disease : Typically presents with transmural inflammation and can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, often with "skip lesions."
  • • Option A. Crohn's Disease
  • • Option C. Infectious Colitis : Usually has a more acute onset and is associated with infectious pathogens; biopsy might show inflammation but not typically crypt abscesses.
  • • Option C. Infectious Colitis
  • • Option D. Ischemic Colitis : Generally occurs in older patients and involves the splenic flexure and descending colon; histology would show ischemic changes rather than crypt abscesses.
  • • Option D. Ischemic Colitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Continuous colonic inflammation with crypt abscesses, particularly in the rectum and sigmoid colon, suggests Ulcerative Colitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most critical diagnostic criterion for toxic megacolon ?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of colonic dilation >6 cm on imaging

questions.correct_answer: A. Presence of colonic dilation >6 cm on imaging
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Presence of colonic dilation >6 cm on imaging

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. History of constipation: While constipation can be a symptom associated with various gastrointestinal conditions, it is not a specific or critical diagnostic criterion for toxic megacolon. Toxic megacolon is more directly identified by imaging showing colonic dilation and systemic signs of toxicity.
  • • Option B. History of constipation:
  • • Option C. Fever and tachycardia: Fever and tachycardia are signs of systemic inflammation and toxicity. They can be present in toxic megacolon but are not specific to this condition. They can occur in various infectious and inflammatory diseases and are not definitive for diagnosing toxic megacolon.
  • • Option C. Fever and tachycardia:
  • • Option D. Electrolyte imbalances: Electrolyte imbalances can occur in many gastrointestinal disorders, including severe diarrhea or vomiting, and can be a consequence of toxic megacolon due to fluid shifts and systemic illness. However, they are not specific diagnostic criteria for toxic megacolon. The primary diagnostic criterion remains colonic dilation >6 cm on imaging.
  • • Option D. Electrolyte imbalances:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Colonic dilation >6 cm on imaging is a key diagnostic criterion for toxic megacolon, especially in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: According to the Forrest classification, a gastric ulcer on the lesser curvature of the stomach is classified as ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Forrest IIa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Forrest Ia: Represents active arterial bleeding, which is not described in the scenario.
  • • Option A. Forrest Ia:
  • • Option B. Forrest Ib: Indicates an active bleed but with a slower, oozing vessel, also not described here.
  • • Option B. Forrest Ib:
  • • Option D. Forrest IIb: It is characterized by an ulcer with an adherent clot, not a visible vessel.
  • • Option D. Forrest IIb:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A gastric ulcer with a visible non-bleeding vessel according to the Forrest classification (Forrest IIa), indicates a high risk of rebleeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with intermittent dysphagia to solids, particularly meat, which improves with swallowing water. He denies any history of heartburn or regurgitation. Upper endoscopy reveals a lesion at the gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schatzki ring

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Achalasia: Achalasia typically presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, and sometimes chest pain, due to the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and absence of esophageal peristalsis.
  • • Option A. Achalasia:
  • • Option B. Esophageal stricture: An esophageal stricture usually results from chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and presents with gradual onset of dysphagia to solids, but it does not present as a circumferential ring at the gastroesophageal junction.
